patterns: what should I do in the morning
responses: Good morning! Start your day with a glass of water and a smile.
Morning tip: Make your bed, stretch a little, and plan your day.

patterns: what should I do before sleeping
responses: Good night! Don’t forget to relax and avoid screens before bed.
Sleep tip: Keep your phone away and let your mind rest.

I can share a joke to cheer you up. I am here!
Why don’t scientists trust atoms in space? Because they make up everything in the universe!
Why did the astronaut break up with his girlfriend? He needed space.
Why don’t aliens visit our solar system? They read the reviews — only one star.
Why did the sun go to school? To get a little brighter.
How do astronauts organize a party? They planet.
What is an astronaut’s favorite key on a keyboard? The space bar.
Why did the cow become an astronaut? To see the moooon.
Why was the astronaut so good at football? Because he always knew how to shoot for the stars.

Why did the star apply for a job? It wanted to shine at work.

Why did Saturn break up with Jupiter? It just needed some ring space.

patterns: tell me a fact about the sun
responses: The Sun is about 4.6 billion years old.
It takes about 8 minutes and 20 seconds for sunlight to reach Earth.
The Sun contains 99.8% of the mass in our solar system.
The Moon is Earth’s only natural satellite.
The Moon is moving away from Earth at a rate of 3.8 cm per year.
There is no atmosphere on the Moon, which means no sound can be heard there.
Mercury is the smallest planet in our solar system.
A year on Mercury is just 88 Earth days.
Temperatures on Mercury can range from -173°C at night to 427°C during the day.
Venus is the hottest planet in the solar system with surface temperatures around 465°C.
A day on Venus is longer than a year—it takes 243 Earth days to rotate once.
Venus rotates in the opposite direction to most planets.
Earth is the only planet known to support life.
70% of Earth’s surface is covered by water.
Earth’s atmosphere protects us from meteors and harmful radiation from the Sun.
Mars is known as the Red Planet due to iron oxide on its surface.
Mars has the tallest volcano in the solar system, Olympus Mons.
A day on Mars (sol) is about 24 hours and 39 minutes.
Jupiter is the largest planet in the solar system.
It has a Great Red Spot, a storm that has been raging for over 300 years.
Jupiter has at least 95 moons, including Ganymede, the largest moon in the solar system.
Saturn is famous for its beautiful ring system made of ice and rock.
Saturn is the least dense planet—it could float in water if there were a bathtub large enough.
Saturn has more than 140 known moons.
Uranus rotates on its side, making it unique among the planets.
A year on Uranus lasts 84 Earth years.
It is often called an 'ice giant' because it is mostly made of water, methane, and ammonia.
Neptune has the strongest winds in the solar system, reaching up to 2,100 km/h.
It was the first planet located through mathematical predictions before being seen through a telescope.
A year on Neptune lasts 165 Earth years.
